dict.string: Consent to join the Developer Health Research Study.
Now you will create a passcode to identify yourself to the app and protect access to information you've entered.
This step concludes the registration process for VascTrac. Next up, you will see main app functionality.
Please try again in five minutes.
VascTrac aims to analyze your mobility data from the study, which may include oxygen levels, pedometer and accelerometer information, and step counts.
Your electronic health records (EHR) stored in Apple Health or other EHR systems provide VascTrac crucial context in analyzing the effect of activity on patient outcomes.
Sign in using your Apple ID is fast and easy, and Apple will not track any of your activities.
We need to confirm your email address and send you a copy of the consent you just signed.
Are you sure you want to withdraw?
Withdrawing from the study will reset the app to the state it was in prior to you originally joining the study.
Thank you for your contribution to this study. We are sorry that you could not continue. The app will now close.

VascTrac is a research study of activity in patients who are considering having an operation. We hope to learn how activity changes over time in people who undergo procedures and how changes in activity could predict your recovery.

You are invited to participate in a research study of activity in patients who are considering having an operation. We hope to learn how activity changes over time in people who undergo procedures and how changes in activity could predict your speed to recovery. You are eligible for this study if you are older than 18 years old and speak English. Health information provided by you and by reviewing your health records will be used to identify trends between physical fitness, participant demographics and outcomes. Furthermore, certain non-personally identifying information collected and analyzed in this study may be shared with external research partner(s). This research study is looking for 1000 participants.
Your participation in this study is entirely voluntary, and you may choose to not participate or withdraw from this study without loss or negative effects on medical care.

Your participation in this study is entirely voluntary. Your decision not to participate will not have any negative effect on you or your medical care. You can decide to participate now but withdraw your consent later and stop being in the study without any loss of benefits or medical care you are entitled to.
Your participation will take about 1 hour per month for 6 months to 1 year. This consists of one-time registration, a weekly walking test, and medical questionnaires every 3 months.

Your participation will take approximately 60 minutes per month for 6 months to one year. The time commitment is broken down as follows: this research study involves three main components. The first component is the registration process. This takes approximately 15 minutes and is only during the initial registration for the study. The second component is a 6-minute walking test, which takes approximately 15-minutes to perform. Participants will be asked to perform a walk test every week with up to four walk tests a month. The third component is filling out questionnaires about your medical history, surgical history and how you are feeling overall. This will be performed every 3 months and will take approximately 10 minutes to perform. If you need help filling out these surveys, you may ask the help of your care provider.
At the conclusion of the study you have the option of deleting/removing the application from your device or may continue using the application. If you continue to use the study application we will also continue collecting activity data for up to 5 years.
More information about what you will be asked to do and the data that will be collected is described below under the headings ‚ÄúPROCEDURES‚Äù and ‚ÄúSTUDY DATA‚Äù.

The investigators will not require any medical procedures to be performed during the study. The investigators will monitor your activity using the activity tracker of your mobile phone and sometimes a research-grade activity tracker (accelerometer). In this study, you will primarily be asked to create a profile, complete medical questionnaires regarding walking impairment, and take 6-minute walking tests.

The investigators will not require any medical procedures to be performed during the study. The investigators will monitor your activity using the activity tracker of your mobile phone and sometimes a research-grade activity tracker (accelerometer). The information described below under ‚ÄòStudy Data‚Äô will be collected by the VascTrac app which you will interact with to complete the tasks below and a second app. If you have questions about this app please contact a VascTrac team member
The researchers may also study any previous physical activity data stored on your phone and will use your electronic health record to document your past medical history.
In the study, you will be asked to do the following: ¬∑ First, create a profile by answering basic demographic information about yourself, including your date of birth, gender, smoking status, and type of planned surgery. ¬∑ Second, complete the Walking Impairment Questionnaire (WIQ). This survey is comprised of 22 questions which ask why, if at all, you had difficulty walking and then ask about the degree of physical activity you have undertaken over the last week. ¬∑ Third, to perform 6-minute walk tests and allow collection of certain activity data, such as your physical activity, accelerometer, gyroscope, and daily movement data in the background. ¬∑ More information about the data that will be collected from you in the study is described below under the heading ‚ÄúSTUDY DATA‚Äù. ¬∑ Finally, to study the effect of app design on protocol compliance, you may be randomly selected to receive newly designed versions of the app as it is updated through the app store and receive different types of reminders, such as a phone call or in-app message.
In case of technical difficulty, you may contact a VascTrac team member who can help you enroll in the study on your phone.

As part of this study, the following information may be collected: contact & demographic information, motion data from walking tests, self-reported medical information, passively monitored activity data, and device metadata.

As part of this study, the information collected from you may include the following (we call this ‚ÄúStudy Data‚Äù): ¬∑ Contact information (e.g. name, email address, and phone number) ¬∑ Demographic information (e.g.. age, gender, height, and weight) ¬∑ Sensor information (e.g. accelerometer, gyroscope, heart rate) ¬∑ Self-reported medical history and current symptom information (e.g. medical diagnosis, test results, medications, symptoms, surgeries) ¬∑ Passive Health Kit data (e.g. steps, walking and running distance, stand hours, flights climbed, heart rate recovery and variability) ¬∑ Device metadata (e.g. Timezone, device operating system version, on/off wrist status)

As a participant, your responsibilities include: ¬∑ Follow the instructions of the investigators and study staff. ¬∑ Complete your questionnaires as instructed. ¬∑ Contact us to ask questions as you think of them. ¬∑ Allow access to Location Services, Push Notifications, and motion sensors on your smartphone.

As a participant, your responsibilities include: ¬∑ Follow the instructions of the investigators and study staff. ¬∑ Complete your questionnaires as instructed. ¬∑ Contact us to ask questions as you think of them. ¬∑ Allow access to Location Services, Push Notifications, and motion sensors on your smartphone.
You may withdraw at any time with no negative effects to medical care. If you want to withdraw, you may do so from the VascTrac App (via the "Leave Study" option in the "Profile" menu).

If you first agree to participate and then you change your mind, you are free to withdraw your consent and stop your participation at any time. If you decide to withdraw from the study, you will not lose any benefits to which you would otherwise be entitled, and your decision will not affect your ability to receive medical care for your condition.
If you withdraw, no additional information will be collected from you but the Study Data that has already been collected from you prior to your withdrawal may be used as described in this consent form.
If you want to stop being in the study you may do so from the VascTrac App. In the ‚ÄúProfile‚Äù menu you will see a ‚ÄúLeave Study‚Äù option. Simply select this option and confirm your selection. If you withdraw from the study, you will not be able to use the VascTrac app anymore.

We will keep your Study Data as confidential as possible. VascTrac will assign a code to your Protected Personal Information, store it in a secure location, and limit access to the data. Only the study's Protocol Directors, necessary units of Stanford University, and Research Staff are authorized to use the data.

We will keep your Study Data as confidential as possible.
Study Data collected from or about you as part of the study that can directly identify you (including your name and address) is called ‚ÄúProtected Personal Information.‚Äù Your Protected Personal Information will be held confidential by the study staff and access limited to those on the study staff who need access in order to administer and conduct the study.
We may publish the results of this study for others to read about, but you will not be identified in any articles about the study by name, social security number, address, telephone number, or any other Protected Personal Information.
Your remaining Study Data will be separated from your Protected Personal Information and will be assigned a key code (we call this ‚ÄúCoded Study Data‚Äù). Information about the Coded Data will be kept in a secure location and access will be limited as described in this consent.
The following parties are authorized to use and/or disclose your Study Data (including your Protected Personal Information and Coded Study Data) in connection with this research to persons and organizations in the next paragraph: The Protocol Directors: Elsie Ross MD, Oliver Aalami MD The Stanford University Administrative Panel on Human Subjects in Medical Research and any other unit of Stanford University as necessary Research Staff
The parties listed in the preceding paragraph may disclose your Study Data to the following persons and organizations for their use in connection with this research study and as described in this consent form: The Office for Human Research Protections in the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services The Food and Drug Administration
Information about your team's use of data.
Information about your team's use of data. Additional content.
